Award.AwardTitle: Catalyst Project: Identification of New Regulators of Endothelial Protein C Receptor Functions

Division.LongName: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

Award.AbstractNarration:
Catalyst Projects provide support for Historically Black Colleges and Universities to work towards establishing research capacity of faculty to strengthen science, technology, engineering and mathematics undergraduate education and research. It is expected that the award will further the faculty member's research capability, improve research and teaching at the institution, and involve undergraduate students in research experiences. This project at Texas College intends to identify and characterize important molecules that affect proteins. Undergraduate students will participate in this research that involves computer modeling. The research results will be used in coursework at Texas College.

This project will identify new small molecular regulators of functions of the physiologically important multifunctional and multi-ligand transmembrane receptor protein â€“ EPCR. Using homology modeling and molecular dynamics simulations, the project will create functionally relevant conformations of EPCR which cannot be found in published structures. Structure based molecular docking of small molecules to these conformations followed by the database searches will identify candidate molecules that will be tested experimentally to reveal their regulatory potential.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Texas College (TC) received an HBCU UP Research Initiation Award of $149,494.00 to support the work towards establishing faculty research capacity and starting undergraduate research at TC that involves underrepresented students. These funds allowed TC to create a laboratory with high-performance computing capabilities and achieve outcomes that address the intellectual merit and broader impacts of the project. Improved TC faculty research capability enabled their collaboration with the research institutions from the University of Texas System with access to the infrastructure for the experimental research. Thus, TC achieved the project’s goal related to improving the research infrastructure.

TC also achieved the second goal of the project: to identify small molecules that can regulate the functions of the Endothelial Protein C Receptor (EPCR). Modeling of the EPCR signaling complex suggested new direct functionally important interactions of the transmembrane domain of EPCR with the Protease-activated receptor 1. Molecular docking and molecular dynamics experiments demonstrated the capability of Arbutamine and Vorapaxar placed in the hydrophobic cleft of EPCR to displace EPCR-bound Protein C.  The molecular dynamics simulation of this system represents a model system for the study of ligand displacement by small molecules. The molecular dynamics simulation of EPCR with two Vorapaxar molecules bound to different regions of EPCR has proven to be an informative model for ligand unbinding studies. The results of modeling EPCR-dependent PAR1 signaling are deposited in BioRxiv. The results of studies on the regulation of EPCR function were presented at the East Texas Research Conference.

The project achieved its goals related to training of students and their exposure to the undergraduate research. Additionally, three-dimensional structural models of proteins, protein-protein complexes, and protein-ligand complexes were used as teaching materials to improve several biology courses. 

 


Last Modified: 10/10/2024
Modified by: Alexei V Iakhiaev
